Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: We [want] to ensure that Jordan‚Äôs growth is green, that it benefits all, and that everyone has access to skills and opportunities to contribute to such growth
Outcome: Outcome 1: Enhanced inclusive, gender-responsive and green growth in Jordan that provides access to entrepreneurship and decent work opportunities, life-long learning, and market-relevant skills with a focus on LNOB
Output: Output 1.5: People‚Äôs access to and use of technologies, digital services and platforms is improved to facilitate an inclusive and green economic transition
Sub-Output: Equitable and inclusive access to financial services, and digital solutions to support self-reliance enhanced
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality; 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is the principal objective
Gender marker narrative: The project aims to address the lack of control of women over financial resources, lack of decision-making power in the household and their businesses, and their ability to have a voice in society and influence policy. It focuses on economic empowerment through access to financial services. It will seek to develop and enhance the use of gender-responsive fintech products and tools to be utilized to increase women‚Äôs activity in the green economy, provide them with access to resources and diminish structural barriers that hinder their full participation in the labour force, including those caused by financial providers. It will also focus on improving the skills and capacities of women, particularly the underserved including rural women, to be able to access digital, financial and non-financial products and services. The actions will target women led MSMEs, self-employed women, and women-led cooperatives. Activities will also involve regulatory authorities and financial service providers to build their capacities to better serve women and offer gender-responsive services.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The project focuses on the empowerment of economically and socially marginalized women by enhancing women‚Äôs engagement in the green economy through financial inclusion. The project is aligned with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and aims to uphold the UN Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Access to digital financing services will facilitate access to markets and other public services for women in rural communities. Enhancing their ability to successfully pursue economic activities will increase their representation and roles as community leaders and agents of change. The human rights-based approach is embedded in the participatory approach of the project, which will start with an assessment of women‚Äôs needs and of barriers to their participation. Local partners and the local community will participate in project planning, implementation, and decision-making throughout the participatory processes.¬†¬†
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Peace, Partnership, and Other Cross-Cutting Issues ‚Äî Foster peaceful, just, and inclusive societies and mobilize the means required for implementation (SDGs 16‚Äì17)
Outcome: Peaceful, just, and inclusive society is adequately fostered, and the means required for the implementation of Agenda 2030 are mobilized
Output: Strengthened capacity of government institutions and multi-stakeholder partnerships promoting improved services and social dialogue to advance a peaceful, just, and inclusive society for all
Sub-Output: Regional Digital Regulation Training Project for ITU Regions Supported by Saudi Arabia
Description:
The ITU Arab Regional Office partnered with the Communications Space & Technology Commission (CST) of Saudi Arabia since 2019 to support the dissemination of digital regulation trainings throughout the various ITU regions, while benefit the Digital Regulation capacity of Saudi Arabia as well. The project is being implemented in three phases of two years each. While the first phases ended in 2022, the first addendum added a third phase to the project that ended in 2024. Currently, the third addendum is being finalized and ready to sign with Saudi Arabia CST in order to implement a third phase for the project that will extend implementation to the end of 2026. The latest regional event supported by the project was a regional digital regulation training for Africa, that took part in 12-22 Nov 2024. The project has played a pivotal role in advancing digital regulation and transformation and strengthening national expertise in Saudi Arabia, which can be regarded currently as a Digital Regulator, especially after Saudi's creation of a National Digital Regulations Committee as part of the impact of this project on the Kingdom. 
Please note that financial contribution from the ITU to this project is assessed based on in kind contribution.
Contributing partners: Core Funding; Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
SDG Targets: 17.6 Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.
SDG Goals: 17 Partnerships for the Goals
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing

Description: Collaborating with the Government of Bahrain to host the ITU Global Skills Forum from 13-17 September in Manama. The ITU Digital Skills Forum is the core global event for the ITU membership and other stakeholders to discuss the most pressing needs that must be addressed to ensure that universal digital skills can be achieved, and the global digital skills gap be closed. This positioned the government of Bahrain further as a regional leader in Digital Skills knowledge sharing.

2023 Narrative: UNDP cooperated with Ministry of Economy and Planning to publish the VNR report and participate in the United Nations High-level Political Forum on Sustainable Development in 2023, to outline Saudi Arabia's achievements in its unwavering commitment to sustainable development. UNDP supported the related institutions in adoption and realization of the SDGs, and all different dimensions and participated in generating the right SDGs statistics and measuring the level of achievement and realization of each of the SDGs and sub-objectives. The project has effectively participated in producing the VNR for the Kingdom which was completed in June 2023 and presented in the UN Conference on realization of SDGs, country-wise. This contributed to UNDP surpassing its 2023 milestone for Output 3.1 Indicator 3.1.2. These achievements reflect Vision 2030's unprecedented reforms and an inclusive approach, highlighting economic development strides, infrastructure investments, and diversification efforts in tourism, technology, and energy. Notably, the Kingdom has prioritized innovation, digitalization, and job creation, with a focus on increasing female labor force participation, which rose from 19.4% in 2015 to 36% in 2022. Multiple large-scale urban development programs are expanding green spaces, pedestrian walkways, and recreational area.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2025-2029)
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Peace - Governance for Justice and Human Rights
Outcome: OUTCOME 3: By 2029, all people living in Bahrain benefit from strengthened governance structures with universal access to justice and human rights protection, enhanced capacities to eliminate discrimination and violence against women and other vulnerable groups , and a public sector that is evidence-based, innovative and efficiently and effectively responsive to the evolving needs of the people.
Output: Output 3.1: Strengthened legal, institutional, and accountability frameworks to uphold justice, human rights, and the rule of law, ensuring gender equality, non-discrimination, and protection of persons with vulnerabilities.
Sub-Output: Sub-Output 3.1.4 (UNESCO) advanced legal frameworks and policies to support digital transformation in the justice sector
Description: Advances legal frameworks by training justice sector stakeholders on the implications of artificial intelligence (AI) for the rule of law. Implemented by UNESCO, this sub-output provides capacity-building on the benefits and challenges of AI in judicial and legal processes. The training program educates judges, lawyers, and court officials on how AI can improve operations (through efficiency and data analysis) and also alerts them to risks such as algorithmic bias, transparency issues, and potential infringements on rights. It offers guidance on principles and emerging regulations for the responsible use of AI in justice, including relevant case law. By developing this understanding, the justice sector will be better prepared to harness technology in ways that enhance access to justice and efficiency while safeguarding equality, non-discrimination, and accountability. This proactive approach helps Bahrain‚Äôs legal system modernize responsibly in step with global trends
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Bahrain Ministry of Justice, Islamic Affairs and Waqf
SDG Targets: 10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.,16.10 Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
SDG Goals: 10 Reduced Inequalities; 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The programme aims at supporting judicial system in the use of AI in an ethical and responsible as well as in dealing with AI related cases, to promote peaceful and just societies and ensure the realisation of human right through a digitally empowered justice system.

2023 Narrative: The comprehensive study and benchmarking of the draft Anti-Corruption Convention against international agreements, including the UN's Conventions against Organized Crime and Corruption, ensured alignment with global best practices. This collaboration between UNDP and the National Anti-Corruption Authority (Nazaha) strengthened the Kingdom's legislative framework, reflecting a commitment to proactively combat global corruption. The efforts enhance Saudi Arabia's role in promoting transparency, integrity, and ethical governance practices internationally. Such activities contributing to indicator 4.1 Statistical performance index increase from 63.4 in 2022 to 80.8 in 2023.Notably with the Saudi Food and Drug Authority, the development and approval of the National Health Technology Assessment (HTA) guideline, along with the updating and implementation of technical regulations and standards in the Food Sector, contributed to public sector excellence. In the Drug Sector, the increase in expertise and international committee appointments, along with the updating of pharmaceutical guidelines and streamlining of sample analysis processes, further supported public sector excellence. These initiatives collectively contributed to the establishment of an inclusive and just society.

Description:
"UNDP‚Äôs Lebanon Public Administrative Reform and Digitalization Project (L-PARDP) is designed to assist the Government of Lebanon in implementing priority key reforms. This initiative links traditional public administration, civil service, and policy reforms with a digital transformation process, aiming at renewing the social contract between the Government and its citizens (in terms of rights and obligations).

L-PARDP is placed to re-activate core government functions and public services and support key decision-making and reform processes while leveraging digital transformation."

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 - 2026
Strategic priority: Planet
Outcome: Planet1: Improved gender inclusive environmental management and governance
Output: Planet1.1: Institutional and policy frameworks and capacities to regulate, and manage pollution, and waste are improved
Sub-Output: Demonstrating digital monitoring and management tools to enhance energy efficiency and reduce emission of green-house gases in the space cooling and cold chain sector
Description:
"GID - Cooling provided by air conditioning and refrigeration systems is essential for sustainable development. However, cooling also generates a serious carbon footprint, directly through the emissions of greenhouse gas refrigerants and indirectly due to the consumption of electricity generated using fossil fuels. Cooling is currently estimated to consume almost 20 percent of the world‚Äôs electricity consumption in buildings. Energy demand for space cooling is expected to triple by 2050 fueled by rising temperatures and economic prosperity. If cooling efficiency is not improved significantly, an increase in greenhouse gas emissions from energy consumption and refrigerants will occur and warm the planet.
Digital tools and Internet of Things (IoT) provide valuable insights, automation, and control capabilities that can significantly enhance the energy efficiency of cooling systems, reducing emission of green-house gases, and identifying energy saving opportunities. By implementing smart cooling strategies and smart cold chain infrastructure, a city can reduce the urban heat island effect, minimize the amount of electricity consumed, which in turn reduces the use of fossil fuels and pressure on the power grid in the peak time.
Despite refrigeration and air conditioning accounting for a significant share of global energy consumption, the application of digitalization to these areas has so far received less attention than for other household appliances and mobility devices. Therefore, it is important to conduct demonstration projects to accumulate experiences for replication in more countries.
This project will research and identify digital tools which can be used to monitor the use of energy. Based on this information, it will pilot the use of such digital tools for the monitoring and development of strategies to minimize energy use."
SDG Targets: 12.1 Implement the 10-year framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production, all countries taking action, with developed countries taking the lead, taking into account the development and capabilities of developing countries.
SDG Goals: 12 Responsible Consumption and Production
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Project initiatives will be implemented in a gender responsive manner and both female and male professionals in the RAC sector gain a comprehensive understanding of the potential benefits and applications of AI and IoT in RAC, and the necessary skills and knowledge in AI and IoT technologies, then gender mainstreaming will be enhanced in the cooling sector and both female and male professionals can actively contribute to the successful integration and implementation of these advanced technologies, contributing to efficiency improvements, energy savings, and enhanced system performance.
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
